FacilityName: E. C. Gaston Electric Generating Plant

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Alabama Power Compamy's Plant E. C. Gaston, located near Wilsonville, Alabama, is a 5 unit steam electric generating plant.  Plant Gaston has two (2) cooling towers to help reduce the temperature of the water that is discharged into the Coosa River.  In order to treat the water, chlorine is injected into the cooling tower system.  Two (2) 1 ton cylinders of chlorine are attached to a manifold for this purpose.  Four (4) additional cylinders are kept as spares in this location.  Therefore, the total quantity of chlorine exceeds the threshold limit of 2500 lbs.  A Process Safety Management  (PSM) program is in effect under OSHA for Plant Gaston, therefore Program 3 applies.

The main hazard that would be associated with the chlorine at Plant Gaston is a toxic hazard.  The most likely event is the leaking of the manifold attached to the cylinders or the rupture of the cylinders.  The cylinders are protected from traffic around the facility by open sided steel framed sheds.  When it is necessary to replace empty cylinders, trained personnel remove and connect full chlorine cylinders to the manifold.  Therefore, a rupture that would result in the rapid release of chlorine is unlikely.  Due to the sparse population around the plant, even the with worst case scenario public exposure would be limited.

The HGSYSTEM (Version 3.0) model was used to determine the worst case and alternate case scenario for the release of chlorine gas.  The model determined that the toxic endpoint occurred at approximately 2.7 miles from the release point for the worst case scenario and 0.3 miles for the alternate case scenario.  The end point for the worst case scenario did contain some public receptors but did not include any environmental receptors.  The alternate case scenario did not contain any public receptors or environmental receptors.  Plant Gaston did not exceed the threshold amounts for flammables.

In order to insure that releases of chlorine do not occur,  daily visual and document

ed weekly inspections are performed by plant personnel.  Plant Gaston also has an outside contractor perform a yearly maintenance inspection on the chlorination system.  We feel these programs greatly reduce the possibility of an accidental release of chlorine. 

Plant Gaston has not had any spills of chlorine in the past 5 years.

Plant Gaston does have a written emergency response plan that includes the release of chlorine.  In the event of a release, this plan would be implemented immediately.  This plan provides for the notification of the local emergency response agencies and the public in the event of a release.  The local emergency response agencies have been notified that chlorine is present at Plant Gaston.
